I've finished the game twice now, on easy and normal. This is a really good soulslite/soulslike beginner-friendly game, very easy to get into. This is a perspective of a player that did not play or did not get far into Dark Souls, Elden Ring and Sekiro.
It's very accessible, and gives you lots of help and tools to succeed and will let you see the full story, including a visual assistant for dodging and parrying on easy mode.

There is indefinite New Game Plus mode, you can keep your outfits and gear and keep going over and over.

When it comes to purchasing, when I went to unlock some hairstyles and (some raunchy) outfits, I was sure because it was a Korean Game that I would have to put out some serious cash, but no, everything in game is in-game currency or achievements (there's costumes in the store as dlc, that's fine)

The Nikke and Nier outfits bought as DLC were earned in a cool minigame and hunt fashion, instead of them just magically showing up in your inventory, have to work for them, which is nice, it feels earned. The Tachy suit is placed on the bridge in the city.

The voice acting is very good, Eve in particular. You can change it to native korean if you want which sounds great too, a little more natural maybe. Performance was pretty okay for me on a 5900x and 5070 on 1440p High. I sat around 70-80 fps, but had to turn down the world 4k textures to high, some rock faces were a bit blurred. I did not experience any crashes. The only issue I had was cutscene stutters, but i believe thats a common unreal engine problem.

The Boss fights have simple mechanics and strategy, doesn't take too long to get the rythym but I haven't completed hard mode yet..there may be too many trash mobs in the open world at times, but they do let you avoid some groups, and some gun types help with groups. I really like the Buildcraft with the exos and augments, cool different types to use, ie-i had to switch to a beta/charge build set to finish the last boss of the game on normal.

The more I play this game, the more interested in the lore and characters, I wasn't completely enthralled with the story, but the game is actually just real fun to play, and not just gooner slop.

The music is absolutely a 10, that soundtracks are constantly living rent-free in my head all the time.

I cannot wait to get my hands on Stellar Blade 2 when it arrives and likely will buy a copy on here and PS5.
If you are interested in Stellar Blade but are not a good player or don't overly like souls games, it might be a good starting point. Be wary though, it is still a souls like game; dodging, parrying, heavy hits, surprise attacks from behind barrels, etc.

Stellar Blade knows exactly what it wants to be and doesn’t pretend otherwise. Tight combat, satisfying parries, flashy skills, and bosses that actually punish bad habits instead of just soaking damage. Once the combat clicks, it’s hard to put down.

The world looks great — ruined cities, weird sci-fi vibes, and solid atmosphere throughout. The soundtrack goes way harder than expected and carries a lot of the big moments. Story isn’t groundbreaking, but it’s good enough to keep you moving forward without getting in the way.

Performance has been solid for me, and the controls feel responsive, which is honestly the most important thing for an action game like this.

Is it perfect? Nah. Some side content feels a bit repetitive, and the story plays it safe at times. But the gameplay absolutely carries the experience.

If you’re into stylish action games with rewarding combat and don’t mind a straightforward story, this is an easy recommend.

Great game for sure, but it’s bogged down with tedium and honestly extremely weak endings.

The action gameplay is fun and fast paced—like a cross between Dark Souls and Nioh. The dodge and parry mechanics are paramount. I played the game in its original Korean dub, and when I compared that to the English dub, there’s no contest—the Korean dub is superior in every way.

The story was interesting, if a little lacking at times. My main gripe is that the main character EVE doesn’t really have an arc. She learns plot-relevant information on her journey and reacts to it, but she doesn’t change as a person by the end and that’s honestly extremely disappointing. And the “tedium” I mentioned was all those damn side quests… I’m cool with side quests but these ones amounted to “find this thing.” After a couple dozen I just kind of abandoned them and plowed through the rest of the story.

I experienced all the endings, even the secret one that I had to look up because I didn’t finish all the side quests, and they’re… serviceable at best and maddeningly hollow at worst. The secret ending is without a doubt the best one but after everything is gone through in-game it just kinda felt like an afterthought.

7.5/10 for this one. I understand a sequel is in development, so I can only hope that they turn out an even better experience.

Так, народ, вытирайте слюни и убирайте руки со стола. Поговорим о Stellar Blade. Если вы зашли в интернет в последние полгода, вы видели Еву. Вы видели её костюмы. Вы видели, как она поднимается по лестнице. Корейцы из Shift Up, конечно, гении маркетинга — продали игру одной «физикой» тела.

Но я тут не для того, чтобы обсуждать размеры полигонов на заднице главной героини (хотя, камон, 10 из 10). Я прошел этот кусок корейского игропрома и сейчас расскажу, есть ли там вообще игра за всем этим латексом.

• Визуал: Корейцы знают, что нам нужно. Давайте сразу закроем тему: да, Ева выглядит так, будто сбежала из влажных снов 15-летнего подростка. Костюмов — гора, и каждый следующий открывает больше кожи, чем предыдущий. Разработчики даже не пытались притворяться, что это «глубокая драма». Но если отвлечься от героини (что сложно), графон реально сочный. Постапокалиптическая Земля, разрушенные города, пустыни — всё блестит, сверкает, Unreal Engine 4 выжат досуха. Враги — какие-то биомеханические уродцы, Найтиба, выглядят мерзко и круто. Дизайнерам монстров — премию, дизайнеру костюмов Евы — памятник при жизни.

• Геймплей: Внезапно, это не просто «симулятор ходьбы». Я ждал, что это будет однокнопочный слэшер, где ты просто мэшишь «квадрат» и смотришь, как трясутся телеса. А вот хрен там плавал.

• Боевка: Это, блин, почти Sekiro, только на каблуках. Парирования, увороты, идеальные блоки. Враги бьют больно. Если будешь тупо жать атаку — тебя размажут по асфальту за две секунды. Импакт от ударов — моё почтение. Ты прям чувствуешь, как меч входит в плоть.

• Сложность: Игра иногда дает прикурить. Некоторые боссы заставляют потеть и материться. Приходится учить паттерны, а не просто любоваться видами. Это стало приятным сюрпризом.

• Прокачка: Древо навыков, экзоскелеты, апгрейды — всё стандартно, но работает. Чувствуешь, как Ева превращается из красивой куклы в машину для убийства.

• Сюжет: Nier: Automata для бедных. Сюжет тут есть, но лучше бы его не было. Андроиды спускаются с космоса, чтобы отбить Землю у монстров. Ничего не напоминает? Да это Nier: Automata, только без гениальности Йоко Таро и философских загонов.

10/10 - Stellar Blade is my absolute favorite game of all time! Pure perfection in every way imaginable. From the moment I booted it up on PC via Steam, I was hooked – this isn't just a game, it's a masterpiece that blends heart-pounding action, a gripping post-apocalyptic sci-fi narrative, jaw-dropping visuals, and an endlessly replayable modding playground that keeps me coming back for hundreds of hours. I've sunk over 250 hours into it already, and I'm nowhere near done. Shift Up nailed everything here, delivering a title that's as beautiful as it is brutal, with Eve as one of the most iconic protagonists in gaming history. 

Let me start with the story because it's one of those tales that sneaks up on you and hits like a freight train. You play as Eve, the last surviving member of the 7th Airborne Squad, descending from the orbiting Colony to reclaim a Naytiba-ravaged Earth. What begins as a straightforward "humanity's savior vs. monstrous invaders" setup evolves into a mind-bending exploration of identity, betrayal, creation, and what it truly means to be human (or Andro-Eidos). The twists in the back half – especially around the Elder Naytiba, Mother Sphere, and the Raphael Marks – had me gasping, replaying cutscenes, and theorizing on forums for days. Characters like Adam, Lily, Tachy, and the enigmatic Raven aren't just sidekicks; their arcs weave emotional depth into the chaos, making every dialogue choice and ally interaction feel weighty. The three epilogues added in updates (plus NG+ expansions) offer multiple endings that reward replayability, turning a 30-hour adventure into a 100+ hour saga of discovery. Sure, some voice acting feels a tad stiff early on, but the Korean/Japanese VO options and orchestral soundtrack elevate every scene to cinematic heights – those boss reveal themes still give me chills! 

The levels? Oh man, they're a design triumph – sprawling, interconnected ruins that feel alive and purposeful, not just empty corridors. Xion is a vibrant hub city buzzing with NPCs, side quests, and secrets; scavenging for Vitcoins, blueprints, and outfit materials here feels rewarding and immersive. Wasteland's dusty expanses hide brutal ambushes and collectibles, while the contaminated zones like the Great Desert and Spire 4 deliver verticality with grapple points, environmental puzzles, and hidden paths that encourage thorough exploration. The Abyss and Tetrapod areas ramp up the horror with grotesque Naytiba nests (those glowing eggs in your screenshots gave me nightmares!), tight platforming, and laser traps that demand precision. Every zone ties into the lore – abandoned colonies, flooded ruins, orbital debris – creating a cohesive world that begs you to 100% it. Side quests aren't filler; they flesh out survivors' stories, unlock crafting mats, and lead to heartfelt moments or epic gear upgrades. And the traversal? Perfect parry-dodges into burst slides, double jumps, and wall-runs make zipping through these levels feel like poetry in motion. 

Gameplay is where Stellar Blade ascends to god-tier. Combat is a symphony of fluidity and satisfaction – Eve's blade combos chain into ranged drone shots, beta skills (those glowing orbs for perfect parries), and burst counters that punish aggression. Upgrading gear at camps (exosuits, drones, amps) lets you experiment with builds: go aggressive with tripods and chainsaws, or tactical with infinite ammo hacks and laser blasters. Bosses are legendary – Gigas' multi-phase stomps, Stalker's acrobatic lunges, Providence's aerial barrages, and the final showdowns demand pattern mastery, perfect timing, and adaptive strategies. Story Mode eases you in with slow-mo aids, but Normal/Hard ramp up the soulslike tension without frustration. Ranged weapons add variety (love sniping weak points mid-combo), and the skill trees branch into endless depth. It's accessible yet challenging, with that "one more try" addiction factor cranked to 11. PC port is flawless – DLSS/FSR, unlocked FPS, ultrawide, even Steam Deck verified at 40-60fps. No Denuvo woes post-crack, pure buttery performance. 

But the REAL joy? MODDING. This is Skyrim-level creativity unleashed! Nexus Mods exploded to 2k+ mods in months – One Stop Camp Shop unlocks ALL 125+ outfits (DLC like Nier 2B, Nikke Scarlet included) instantly, no NG+ grind. Play as Tachy, first-person view, infinite beta energy for spamfests, or Ultimate Engine Tweaks for 200+ FPS on mid-rigs. Outfits? Infinite: Psylocke X-Men skins, Bayonetta glasses/hair, Mai Shiranui cheongsams, bunny suits, even Thomas the Tank Engine bosses! Custom NanoSuits let you mix/match – Eve in Alita armor, Viessa bikinis, or pregnancy mods (wild community). Mod Hub/Vortex make installs drag-and-drop easy (~mods folder in Paks). Director Kim Hyung-tae loves it: "Once purchased, it belongs to the user!" Replayability skyrockets – new outfits per run, QoL cheats, reshaders for neon glow-ups (those bioluminescent eggs pop!), menu randomizers. I've spent 100 hours modding alone: red Ocean Strings, Eve x Dark Rift crossovers, eye/makeup tweaks. It's a living game, community-driven evolution that fixes "middling" bits like photo mode (fan patches incoming). No microtransactions, just pure player freedom.

I'll admit, I came into playing this game not expecting much but fan service (which I'm a fan of) but was amazingly surprised on how polished the game was. I have not yet completed the story at the time of me writing this review but I'm nearly completing it since I'm focused on exploring the world and interacting with side quests and NPCs. That alone is testament that a game is well done that the mini games and world building keeps you distracted from playing the main story.

I'm going to break my review into three parts, the gameplay, story, soundtrack and extra stuff

Gameplay - Fantastic
I think the only gripe I have with the gameplay is that it couldn't allow me to play on hard mode until I beat the game which was a bummer. Despite that, I was amazed on how engaging the gameplay was, and wish that these mechanics were incorporated in other hack and slash games like the NieR series and such. The gameplay always tries to switch things up to make sure that you aren't always doing the same thing over and over, whether that'd be solving passwords/puzzles, interacting with objects to get across platforms, or changing your approach of fighting an enemy depending on their weakness. The combat itself is probably one of my favorite aspects of this game, I absolutely love games that incorporate the parry system and I'm proud to say that this game didn't half ass it and made it a viable alternative instead of dodging (Take notes Fromsoft). On top of that, the animations of Eve slashing her enemies, parrying, doing finishers, is BEAUTIFUL. You can tell a lot of care was put into making these animations look as badass/sexy as possible, props to ShiftUp for delivering. The games progression system is based off earning points which you can invest into Eve's skill tree which gets expanded as you play the game more, and it's great since you can invest into a playstyle that YOU want, reminded me of Sekiro. When you're not fighting enemies, you're platforming and the game does a great job at making you appreciate the sceneary and making things cinematic for you. As for the enemies, I enjoyed most of them although some got to be frustrating (looking at you invisible starfish), but the grotesque design of them made it very unique and made me happy that I wasn't just fighting robots or something non threatening. You can even fish in this game for god's sake. All in all, great across the board.

Story - Great

Take my opinion on the story with a grain of salt since I have not yet finished the story yet, but from what I have seen so far, I'm impressed with the characters that they introduced to us. Some are alot more flat and boring (mainly the soldiers of Xion) but besides that, the main cast are very likeable. Adam is the first dude you meet in the game who helps Eve out and his JP actor is someone I instantly recognized so I knew I was going to vibe with him and I did. Very down to earth and competent, and his banter with Lily is great. Lily is the third member of the squad who's like your typical tomboy energetic mechanic, really what more is there to say or like? I like that she is one of the few characters that questions the objective and plot of what's going on, while Adam is more compliant which is odd but interesting. Last but not least is Eve, the poster girl and waifu we all adore. She's clueless in that she doesn't know what Earth and human practices are like but it makes sense for her since they were in outer space so it's always cute to see Eve discover things that we do in our daily lives as fascinating, similar to 9S explaining humans to 2B. It makes me annoyed that people had the nerve to trash on Eve for her figure and looks despite her being as innocent as one can be personality wise, goes to show why you shouldn't trust tr00ns or obese women on what makes a women beautiful, men know what gets them going and it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that Eve does. Honorable mentions are NPCs such as Enya and Su, the ones who hang around in the bar. I absolutely loved the side quest with these two characters, and was the one that stood out to me the most. I'm a sucker for late night jazz bars, and this one hit home for me.

Soundtrack + Extras - Kino

The soundtrack is insanely good, I was impressed how every single area in the game had it's own unique soundtrack, and it stood out too! Some tracks were so good that it was actually annoying leaving the area and not being able to hear it again since it was reserved for a small section in the map. The campfire music is peaceful and soothing and the alternative options that you can choose from on the disc player are great too (I've been playing Blur a lot). The boss music was pretty good, although none of them hit home for me besides Tachy, and I love that they kept her music when you transform to her form as Eve. I still think that the environmental map soundtracks are the best, and Silent Street from Edios 7 which is the first area that the player enters in is the best track. I think it encapulates the overall theme of the game quite well. Well done ShiftUp, they always get great composers for their games (Destiny Child and NIKKE). 

As for the extras, let's start off with the fan service. PEAK. There are so many outfits that Eve has, from a schoolgirl outfit, to casual blue jeans and a shirt, to a one piece swimsuit with tanlines. I mean the possibilities were endless and they knew that when making these outfits. All of them manage to make Eve's booty look great which is not hard to do if you look at her overall figure and who she was modelled from IRL. I was impressed that they gave us such a range of options for us and them being collectables too was a nice bonus. My favorite Eve outfit has to be Wave Oblique Monokini, why? CAUSE TANLINES. The problem with all these outfits is now that you've seen how good they look, you HAVE to get them all and it can be annoying having to look every single place in an area to make sure you don't miss anything.

Overall - Highly Recommend

[h2]Stellar Blade — My Thoughts[/h2]

Stellar Blade absolutely swept me off my feet. From the moment the game starts, it pulls you into this gorgeous, broken world that somehow feels both haunting and beautiful. I fell in love with everything — the side quests that actually feel meaningful, the stunning soundtrack that hits at just the right moments, the jaw-dropping visuals, and of course, the incredible main heroine who carries the whole journey with style and heart.

The story grabbed me way harder than I expected. The endings left me thinking about the characters long after the credits rolled. It’s one of those games that stays with you — not because it forces deep messages, but because it feels sincere.

The combat? Addictive. It nails that perfect balance: slasher energy with souls-like tension, but never to the point of being suffocating. Challenging, yes — but in a fun, “I can totally do this” way that keeps your adrenaline going.

Sure, there are a few rough edges — some parkour moments get buggy, and a couple of things could’ve been smoother overall — but honestly, those tiny issues melted away in the bigger picture.

At the end of the day, Stellar Blade is a game I wholeheartedly recommend to anyone who wants a stylish, emotional, action-packed adventure that respects your time and rewards your effort. It’s bold, it’s beautiful, and it’s absolutely worth experiencing.

Stellar Blade has exceeded all my expectations, as I walked into it thinking this game would just be like any other sci-fi shooter, but instead, I ended up getting far more involved than I ever thought I would be. 

The story had my full undivided attention while I played the game. Not only is the plot compelling, but it also has scenes that provide the player with a meaningful and emotional connection to the game, which is unlike many games today that seem forced. The world lore also feels immense, and the pacing throughout the whole game kept me engaged enough to never want to skip cutscenes like most games today does.

The combat experience in this game is fantastic and has been the highlight of Stellar Blade. After I got used to the timing of the combat mechanics, it was fast-paced, flashy, and surprisingly complicated, but in a fun way! Every single battle I felt was important, and the combination of dodging, parrying, and putting in my special abilities worked so well together. The idea of wanting to try “one more time” when I took damage or even died was something special, and seeing how well I performed my combos was a good feeling.

The visuals in this game are absolutely amazing. Stellar Blade has incredible graphics both in the environments and in the open world, but also in the character models, and the lighting effects are also breathtaking. There were multiple occasions when I would simply stop playing and admire the incredible graphics before me.

Overall, Stellar Blade is one of those games that looks amazing, plays great, and actually backs it up with a legit, emotional, and fun story. It is definitely worth your time if you’re into sci-fi action games or just want something that feels fun as well as polished from start to finish.

[h3]The Combat[/h3]
The combat I think has potential but I have a feeling the game can't really decide wheater it wants to be a character action game or a Souls-like/Sekiro-like. Sure it has a variety of strings but they are not that good and your main source of damage are the skills that are tied to beta (blue) and alpha (red) meter.
And the fact that you have only one weapon for the entire game doesn't really help.
And combat feels bad when theres more than one enemy around you.
Also it has a Tachy mode (local devil trigger) which gives you invincibility but in terms of damage it's a joke, so you'll end up using it just as a suvival tool IMO.
On normal NG the combat feels not so good but I on hard with NG+ starts to feel decent, but it still suffers from points i mentioned from above.

[h3]Bosses and Mobs[/h3]
Bosses are fun (most of them) and i like that they and the mobs follow a single artstyle (even if they are generic).
[h3]Story & Quests[/h3]
Side quests are either fetch quests or kill stuff (straight out of korean mmo). There are like a few memorable quests that can tell some story.
The main story itself is very bland (basically Nier Automata but worse) so as the characters (espetially Adam) and only Raven & Lily are interesting (Kaya is cutie tho).
Eve while looks very pretty has a personality of plank of wood through the entire game. She has a character growth and someting interesting going on but the problem is when that happens the game just ends.

[h3]Locations and presentation[/h3]
The visuals look pretty and the game is well optimized which is great.
The soundtrack is an absolute banger and goes straight into my playlist.
The two open world are Desert and Desert 2 (really) so I hope you really like deserts. And most of points of interest are enemy camps with a chest or other collectable.
The locations looks great at the beginning and endgame and great music really adds up the atmosphere. But in midgame locations are forgettable. Since aside from 2 deserst you get underground labs and a sewer.
Oh, and platforming sucks. I won't elaborate.

[h3]Collectables and stuff I guess..[/h3]
Unfortunately the absolute majority of collectable character logs are just some dude's last words that add absolutely nothing interesting.
At least Eve has a LOT of colletable costumes to collect which are great. And many more to unlock (most are recolours but also new ones in NG++). And even more costumes from collab DLCs if you bought them.
The puzzles are straight from kindergarten and add nothing to the game.

[h1] Stellar Blade is an ALRIGHT game that sometimes manages to be a GOOD game but always fails to be a GREAT game. [/h1]

To be transparent, I haven't completed the game yet, but my motivation to actually continue is quite low due to a variety of reasons. I praised the demo for it's great visuals, soundtrack and intruiging combat. I thought that the game would add a bit more depth to that system - oh how wrong I was.

Stellar Blade's combat isn't terrible, but it's quite shallow. The game is extremely lenient even when not on an easy mode and ignoring the free revives (why do they exist!?). I don't mind the game being a bit easier, but the game really lacks depth. Almost all the bosses that I have fought thus far are a pushover and become boring pretty fast. For some of the bosses it feels like they aren't really trying to kill me. Their so not aggressive in any way and a lot of them have range attacks that barely even try to hit you. Running in a circle is enough to avoid em, and that is not all too engaging.

EVE's arsenal can be quite boring too. The drone is probably the best addition, but T mode is extremely strong with very little downside or brain power needed. Burst skills are also not that engaging usually. Overall, the skill ceiling is almost as low as the skill floor, yet your character is very powerful - which transforms most fights into pushovers. It is only when you are deprived of healing or have to deal with weird movement that the game actually becomes a challenge.

Speaking of which: - movement can feel a bit clunky, though I had less issues with it than my friend or some other people that I talked to, though I have to admit that the parkouring in this game feels REALLY bad to control a lot of the time.

Another issue with Stellar Blade is that on occasion you have huge, open areas to explore, which due to their scale feel kinda empty. SHIFTUP tried to combat this by adding tons of enemies that patrol the map, which doesn't result in fun enemy encounters however. It just forces you into combat on occasion while you walk around a huge empty area doing some dogshit quest that contributes very little to the story and is basically just fetching some random item from somewhere. The quests overall are a major reason as to why I am not continuing right now. Yes I know; they are optional. But some of them give new outfits or even some decently written story lines, you just never know which ones are good and which ones are bad. I don't feel like missing out on major content with this game because I know that I probably won't replay it much unless people make fun mods.

In terms of Story: Most of the characters feel extremely flat. I like EVE, but her character is not well explored at all. Which is weird because you get some cute and interesting scenes at the very start of the game, but the developers do nothing with her. Same goes for Adam. Raven is more interesting at the moment but we'll see.

Overall, the story is just as shallow as the gameplay. Stellar Blade has a fuck ton of cutscenes but in the end it's a lot of talk that rings hollow. The main cast is not that well developed and the ''big twists'' halfway through the game left little impact on me. The game director himself admitted that the story was lacking, but blamed it on budget constrains, which I don't think is a good excuse. The game has an entire logbook for all the characters and enemy types, yet they barely use it to add more to the lore! Lots of it is just recap or basic shit. Enemy descriptions are barren. I am not one to complain about fanservice, not at all, I think it's great! But to me it feels like EVE is just a pretty girl slapped on top of a mediocre to alright hack'n slash to compensate for a weak story and shallow combat.

If you're gonna buy this game, get it on a sale because 70€ is waaay too much for any game, especially Stellar Blade. My review might've been more positive if it was priced accordingly.

First off: I don't typically play this style of game, so I'm obviously going to struggle more than someone who is far more familiar with this type of game, but I can accept that.

And I'll be honest, maybe this game's style of combat just isn't for me, but the game so far has proven itself to be more irritating than fun. 

There are some minor gripes that I have with the game, such as, but not limited to; fixed savestations rather than just saving via the menu (this is honestly kind of a big one), having save-tokens rather than just being able to override a savegame whenever and however many times, menu navigation, awkward default keybindings, some odd movement "quirks" (such as the walk toggle disabling whenever I stop pressing a movement key, making navigating small short-distance spaces like the camps annoying, dodging before sprinting, etc.), and a few more than I can't be bothered to list.

Aside from the appalling performance that introduces consistent stuttering for a solid 5-10 seconds every 60 seconds despite running it on low graphics with a GTX3070, 12th gen i7 and 32GB of RAM certainly does not help my enjoyment, and makes boss battles significantly harder than they already are, the combat just does not feel all that fair to me. Though, that is not because of the combat itself, moreso the aforementioned performance issues, and some of the mechanics themselves. (At least, to my experience)

It feels like my button presses are queued up rather than being direct inputs, leading to combos during situations where I'd rather take a few steps back or to the side to avoid an attack. I find myself spamming shift to get out of the way, only to find EVE continuing to hammer at an enemy.

The targeting is another issue. Just a bit ago from writing this review, I had to deal with 3 enemies at once, which, while not ideal, I should be able to deal with it, and I could. However, it's kind of a problem when I'm locked on to an enemy that's behind a wall while my cursor is over an enemy next to me, and instead I'm continuing to bash this wall instead of doing damage to an enemy that I could actually hit and kill.

And then there's the matter of enemy attacks. If an enemy is swinging its big heavy sword (or whatever they might be using) over its head, my instinct is to move out of the path of the sword. I don't *dodge* out of the way, I just *move* out of the way, because that seems the reasonable thing to do, because why the hell would I dodge when I can just move and attack when it's exposed? (In theory, at least) Yet, the entire character just rotates around its X axis, and still swings and hits me. That just doesn't seem like something that should be possible.

Sure, much of my frustrations with this game is just me. I'm not very good at it, and I'm not used to these sorts of games, so they don't come as naturally to me than it would to someone more familiar with them. However, the aforementioned issues for me make the game rather frustrating, and overall, not a very enjoyable experience.

I don't dislike it enough to refund it (and I'm kinda too lazy), but honestly, I can't recommend it.

Also, the music doesn't feel like it matches the gameplay except for the boss battles. For the most part, it just sounds like generic background music, but that's just my opinion.

Customization

Photo mode

Ambience

[h1] Stellar Blade is an ALRIGHT game that sometimes manages to be a GOOD game but always fails to be a GREAT game. [/h1]

To be transparent, I haven't completed the game yet, but my motivation to actually continue is quite low due to a variety of reasons. I praised the demo for it's great visuals, soundtrack and intruiging combat. I thought that the game would add a bit more depth to that system - oh how wrong I was.

Stellar Blade's combat isn't terrible, but it's quite shallow. The game is extremely lenient even when not on an easy mode and ignoring the free revives (why do they exist!?). I don't mind the game being a bit easier, but the game really lacks depth. Almost all the bosses that I have fought thus far are a pushover and become boring pretty fast. For some of the bosses it feels like they aren't really trying to kill me. Their so not aggressive in any way and a lot of them have range attacks that barely even try to hit you. Running in a circle is enough to avoid em, and that is not all too engaging.

EVE's arsenal can be quite boring too. The drone is probably the best addition, but T mode is extremely strong with very little downside or brain power needed. Burst skills are also not that engaging usually. Overall, the skill ceiling is almost as low as the skill floor, yet your character is very powerful - which transforms most fights into pushovers. It is only when you are deprived of healing or have to deal with weird movement that the game actually becomes a challenge.

Speaking of which: - movement can feel a bit clunky, though I had less issues with it than my friend or some other people that I talked to, though I have to admit that the parkouring in this game feels REALLY bad to control a lot of the time.

Another issue with Stellar Blade is that on occasion you have huge, open areas to explore, which due to their scale feel kinda empty. SHIFTUP tried to combat this by adding tons of enemies that patrol the map, which doesn't result in fun enemy encounters however. It just forces you into combat on occasion while you walk around a huge empty area doing some dogshit quest that contributes very little to the story and is basically just fetching some random item from somewhere. The quests overall are a major reason as to why I am not continuing right now. Yes I know; they are optional. But some of them give new outfits or even some decently written story lines, you just never know which ones are good and which ones are bad. I don't feel like missing out on major content with this game because I know that I probably won't replay it much unless people make fun mods.

In terms of Story: Most of the characters feel extremely flat. I like EVE, but her character is not well explored at all. Which is weird because you get some cute and interesting scenes at the very start of the game, but the developers do nothing with her. Same goes for Adam. Raven is more interesting at the moment but we'll see.

Overall, the story is just as shallow as the gameplay. Stellar Blade has a fuck ton of cutscenes but in the end it's a lot of talk that rings hollow. The main cast is not that well developed and the ''big twists'' halfway through the game left little impact on me. The game director himself admitted that the story was lacking, but blamed it on budget constrains, which I don't think is a good excuse. The game has an entire logbook for all the characters and enemy types, yet they barely use it to add more to the lore! Lots of it is just recap or basic shit. Enemy descriptions are barren. I am not one to complain about fanservice, not at all, I think it's great! But to me it feels like EVE is just a pretty girl slapped on top of a mediocre to alright hack'n slash to compensate for a weak story and shallow combat.

The game is actively holding itself back. It has so many great ideas but often times fails to really capitalize on them. Also, the yellow paint is annoying and stupid.

The best part about this game really is the music and visuals (despite some typical unreal engine issues persisting). Performance wise it's pretty good I'd say, but not recommended for lower end PC's. Though I find it odd that the game doesn't run that much better on a lot of the empty open areas, especially the desert.

I am simply tired of so many reused enemies and bosses. Tired of the uninteresting story. Tired of the sluggish combat. Stellar Blade can be a fun game, but when I compare it to other titles in my library, I see little reason to boot it up. If you're gonna buy this game, get it on a sale because 70€ is waaay too much for any game, especially Stellar Blade. My review might've been more positive if it was priced accordingly.

I would like to offer an alternative opinion to keep others from spending a lot of money on a game they might not enjoy. Although the game is solid, I cannot recommend it at the very high AAA price point it occupies at the time of review. I am neutral on the culture war thing surrounding the game - for me, it is perfectly fine to have eyecandy as a protagonist, even though I am personally not aroused by a pixelbutt.

Gameplay (6/10)
The strength of Stellar Blade is certainly the combat system. It rewards player skill, is fast-paced and responsive. Most bosses have interesting movesets. For me, that's about it - but since you spend a lot of your time fighting, it might be enough for some. It might also be worth mentioning that I didn't consciously encounter a single bug, albeit one CTD.
There is a mix of open world areas and dungeon-like linear zones. The open world reminded me a lot of MMORPGs in quest quality, you hunt 5 monsters, take 10 pictures and catch 3 fish. I found exactly one quest in which I was emotionally involved. There are very few items actually worth exploring for - you collect different currencies all the time, most of which are next to useless and do not further your combat ability. 90% of the things you find will be for cosmetic purposes. So make sure this is enough to motivate you, there is no "loot hunting" like in Borderlands. The areas are wastelands and deserts (literally) with a bland color palette and no interesting quests or stories to find. Invisible walls are used to keep you from going or jumping where Eve obviously could, making the exploration even more tedious.

The dungeon-like levels I consider to be better and offer some variation, but they make heavy use of imprecise platforming, overuse jump scares, and even recycle bosses.

The skill trees in the game are bloated - most of the time I was running around with 15 skill points to spare, because there was nothing to spend them on which would have improved my playstyle. You level up quickly and will have bought all important skills by midgame.

Story/Writing (3/10)
Oh boy. The overall premise is good enough and could have been shaped into something decent. But I am convinced a random AI could have done a much better job at writing. We collect X blobs to create a superblob, and the superblob will help us defeat the elder boss. The main twist was hinted towards so early that you could spot it from a mile away. The dialogue has zero emotion, exacerbated by the english voice acting. There is no chemistry between the characters and our protagonist has no personality at all. This is a waste, she could have become an iconic hero like Lara Croft.

Graphics (6/10)
You can tell they spent a lot of time on the character model of Eve, her motion capturing and her outfits. It can also be fun to "dress for the occasion", but it's not enough for me to make a game. The facial and head animations, as well as the gestures, are barebone and distractingly bad. The rarely fit to what is said, the faces are largely emotionless. NPCs in town make "bah bah bah" movements with their mouth, accompanied by a blank stare. It again gives me the impression of playing an MMORPG. Enemies/Bosses are well designed, everything else looks bland with little artistic value.

Sound (6/10)
The english voiceover adds, as mentioned, to the lacking presentation of the story. Eve herself is okay, the rest sounds like they read the ingredients list on a shampoo bottle. It seems that a lot of people enjoy the music, so I am rating it higher than I personally would. On average I'd consider it mediocre and it would never have stood out positively for me (like it did in Clair Obscur). Some tracks are good, but they are used rarely and do not supplement the emotions of the story. Instead, you will be hit by a 3 minute vocal song on a loop while exploring an area for two hours. It was one of the very few instances in which I actually had to turn off the music in a game.

Overall (5/10)
I am aware this is controversial given the ... stellar ratings the game has enjoyed. They drove me to buy the game at a high price and regretting it. If you are on the fence, wait a bit until it is half price.

First off: I don't typically play this style of game, so I'm obviously going to struggle more than someone who is far more familiar with this type of game, but I can accept that.

And I'll be honest, maybe this game's style of combat just isn't for me, but the game so far has proven itself to be more irritating than fun. 

There are some minor gripes that I have with the game, such as, but not limited to; fixed savestations rather than just saving via the menu (this is honestly kind of a big one), having save-tokens rather than just being able to override a savegame whenever and however many times, menu navigation, awkward default keybindings, some odd movement "quirks" (such as the walk toggle disabling whenever I stop pressing a movement key, making navigating small short-distance spaces like the camps annoying, dodging before sprinting, etc.), and a few more than I can't be bothered to list.

Aside from the appalling performance that introduces consistent stuttering for a solid 5-10 seconds every 60 seconds despite running it on low graphics with a GTX3070, 12th gen i7 and 32GB of RAM certainly does not help my enjoyment, and makes boss battles significantly harder than they already are, the combat just does not feel all that fair to me. Though, that is not because of the combat itself, moreso the aforementioned performance issues, and some of the mechanics themselves. (At least, to my experience)

It feels like my button presses are queued up rather than being direct inputs, leading to combos during situations where I'd rather take a few steps back or to the side to avoid an attack. I find myself spamming shift to get out of the way, only to find EVE continuing to hammer at an enemy.

The targeting is another issue. Just a bit ago from writing this review, I had to deal with 3 enemies at once, which, while not ideal, I should be able to deal with it, and I could. However, it's kind of a problem when I'm locked on to an enemy that's behind a wall while my cursor is over an enemy next to me, and instead I'm continuing to bash this wall instead of doing damage to an enemy that I could actually hit and kill.

And then there's the matter of enemy attacks. If an enemy is swinging its big heavy sword (or whatever they might be using) over its head, my instinct is to move out of the path of the sword. I don't *dodge* out of the way, I just *move* out of the way, because that seems the reasonable thing to do, because why the hell would I dodge when I can just move and attack when it's exposed? (In theory, at least) Yet, the entire character just rotates around its X axis, and still swings and hits me. That just doesn't seem like something that should be possible.

Sure, much of my frustrations with this game is just me. I'm not very good at it, and I'm not used to these sorts of games, so they don't come as naturally to me than it would to someone more familiar with them. However, the aforementioned issues for me make the game rather frustrating, and overall, not a very enjoyable experience.

I don't dislike it enough to refund it (and I'm kinda too lazy), but honestly, I can't recommend it.

Also, the music doesn't feel like it matches the gameplay except for the boss battles. For the most part, it just sounds like generic background music, but that's just my opinion.
